title: Burst water pipe in Finsbury Park turned roads into rivers
text:
The north London neighbourhood of Finsbury Park has been hit by flooding (Picture: PA)

Roads turned into gushing rivers this morning after a burst pipe flooded parts of a London neighbourhood.

Residents from 150 properties had to be evacuated after they were left ankle-deep in dirty brown water in Finsbury Park.

Vast swathes of north London were also left with water problems, according to Thames Water.

Firefighters on a flooded street in Finsbury Park, north London (Picture: PA)

A flooded street in Finsbury Park, north London (Picture: PA)

A resident looks at their wet feet in Finsbury Park, north London (Picture: PA)

Specialists and 80 firefighters rushed to the junction of Queen’s Drive and Princess Crescent this morning.

Resident Abi Glover, 27, said that the flat below her was ‘completely flooded.’

She said: The water started at 7.40am and it has not stopped. Everyone has been wading out with no shoes on.

‘The police had a go at me for leaving, but I am in a flooded building.

‘It’s like a river out there, I think that’s why police had a go at me – because the current is so strong.’

Cats and other pets had to be rescued from the flood water (Picture: PA)

Rescue workers speak to a resident after a street in Finsbury Park, north London, flooded when a pipe burst on Tuesday morning (Picture: PA)

A resident walks down a flooded street in Finsbury Park, north London (Picture: PA)

A London Fire Brigade spokesman said the flooding had affected a 500 square metre area and residents were being evacuated.

Nearby Parkwood Primary School had to close as it was left without running water.

Thames Water said that the burst water main was causing the following areas to experience low water pressure or a loss of supply: Highbury, Highbury Fields, Canonbury, Kings Cross, Islington, Pentonville, De Beauvoir Town, Hoxton, Camden, Holloway, and parts of Barnsbury and Tufnell Park.

Matthew Christian, who lives next to Manor House underground station, said: ‘It’s really shocking to see that amount of water flooding the streets with such power that it’s ripping up the road and rushing down the street into people’s front gardens.

‘It’s not the kind of thing you expect to see in Finsbury Park on a Tuesday morning in October.

‘The water is ankle-deep in some parts. I saw some people coming out of their homes where the water was going in and wading up towards us.’

Parked cars are part submerged after the pipe burst (Picture: PA)

Firefighters have been working all day on the flooded streets (Picture: PA)

Hackney London Borough Council said it will be opening a rest centre for residents whose homes have been affected.

Locals said they were worried about elderly residents as video footage showed fast-moving waters flowing down the streets.

A Thames Water spokesman said: ‘We’re sorry to any customers affected by our burst main this morning. We’ve sent our specialist engineers to the scene as a top priority, and they will be working hard to get everything back to normal as soon as possible.’
